chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The system definition file contains instructions for building Linux operating system distributions for use in installing client machines. It defines system content and configuration, including name, version, and architecture; package repository locations; which packages to include; and the locations of configuration scripts, files and custom graphics. SystemStudio uses the system distribution file to assemble, create and publish the system distribution. Other programs, such as YUM, Anaconda, and RPM use files created by SystemStudio to install and update the system distribution on the client system.

The system definition file is a text-based file in XML format. Within the file are a series of top-level elements that equate to modules, or steps, within the system distribution build process. These elements, in turn, contain their own attributes and elements. There are three required top-level elements: , , and ; all other top-level elements are optional. Top-level elements can appear in the system distribution file in any order. Indentation is for readability purposes only.
The system definition file has full support of XML Inclusions (XIncludes). Please refer to the XInclude Technical Report for more information.
A system definition file can be located in any local directory and invoked from the command line using the command systemstudio followed by the full or relative pathname to the file, such as:

section.title: Example System Definition
section.para: Here is a basic example system definition based on CentOS 5.

informalexample.programlisting:
<system distribution>
<main> <name>samba</name> <version>5</version> <arch>i386</arch> </main>
<repos> <repo id="base"> <name>CentOS-$releasever - Base</name> <baseurl>http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/</baseurl> </repo> <repo id="updates"> <name>CentOS-$releasever - Updates</name> <baseurl>http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/updates/i386/</baseurl> </repo> </repos>
<packages> <group repoid="base">core</group> <group repoid="base">smb-server</group> </packages>
</system>

section.title: Top-Level Elements
section.para:
Each top-level element in the SDFR maps to a code module of the same name. Each code module is responsible for performing a single step in the system distribution build process. Related modules are organized into module groups. To obtain a list of all available modules and module groups type
systemstudio --list-modules
at the command prompt. Refer to the SystemStudio man pages for more information. This document only describes top-level elements that contain user-configurable parameters; not all modules listed from the above command are described below.

All top-level elements, including those not described in the following document, support the following method for enabling and disabling the module's processing code. A top-level element element can be disabled by setting element/@enabled to FALSE. Similarly, the module groups rpmbuild, package, and installer can be disabled by setting their @enabled attribute to FALSE.
The sole exception to the above rules is the main module, which is required for SystemStudio to operate properly.

The following example will disable the config top-level element and associated code module:
<config enabled="false" />
The entire rpmbuild module group, which includes config, is disabled like in the following example:
<rpmbuild enabled="false" />
